document:
Understanding Attacks
Attack: An attempt to gain unauthorized access to system resources, data, or services.
Attacks target confidentiality, integrity, or availability (CIA Triad).
Can be technical (software exploitation) or human-based (social engineering).

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 1.pptx

document:
Attack Categories
• Passive attacks – eavesdropping, traffic analysis
• Active attacks – data modification, spoofing, DoS
• Insider attacks – misuse by authorized users
• External attacks – performed by outsiders or hackers

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 1.pptx

document:
Threat Actors
• Script Kiddies – use pre-built tools, limited knowledge
• Hacktivists – politically or socially motivated
• Organized Crime – financial gain
• State-sponsored – espionage or warfare
• Insider Threats – employees or contractors

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 1.pptx

document:
Attack Vectors
The path or means used to breach a system.
Common vectors:
• Phishing emails
• Malicious websites
• USB or external media
• Exploiting vulnerabilities
• Supply chain compromise

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 1.pptx

document:
Malware Overview
Malicious software designed to disrupt, damage, or gain unauthorized access.
Categories include:
• Viruses
• Worms
• Trojans
• Ransomware
• Spyware / Adware
• Rootkits

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 1.pptx

document:
Viruses
• Attach to legitimate programs or files
• Require user action to spread
• Can corrupt or delete data
• Example: Melissa (1999), infected Word documents via email

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 1.pptx

document:
Worms
• Self-replicating malware that spreads without user action
• Exploits vulnerabilities in network services
• Consumes bandwidth and system resources
• Example: Code Red, Slammer, Conficker

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 1.pptx

document:
Trojans
• Disguised as legitimate software
• Often delivered via email attachments or fake updates
• Provide attackers remote control or data access
• Example: Zeus banking trojan

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 1.pptx

document:
Ransomware
• Encrypts victim data and demands payment for decryption
• Often spread through phishing or RDP vulnerabilities
• Notable examples: WannaCry, Petya, LockBit
• Prevention: backups, patching, user education

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 1.pptx

document:
Spyware and Adware
• Spyware monitors user activity, steals credentials or data
• Adware displays unwanted ads or pop-ups
• Often bundled with freeware
• Solution: anti-spyware tools, cautious downloads

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 1.pptx

document:
Rootkits
• Hide the presence of malware or attackers
• Operate at the kernel or application level
• Make detection and removal difficult
• Prevention: secure boot, signed drivers, integrity checks

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 1.pptx

document:
Social Engineering
• Manipulating people into revealing confidential information
• Common forms:
  – Phishing (email fraud)
  – Pretexting (false identity)
  – Baiting (infected media)
  – Tailgating (following into secure areas)
• Defense: awareness training and verification procedures

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 1.pptx

document:
Denial of Service (DoS) Attacks
• Overload systems or networks to disrupt service
• Distributed DoS (DDoS) uses multiple compromised hosts
• Targets: web servers, DNS, APIs
• Mitigation: rate limiting, filtering, CDN protection

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 1.pptx

document:
Man-in-the-Middle (MITM)
• Intercepts communication between two parties
• Techniques: ARP spoofing, DNS poisoning, SSL stripping
• Mitigation: TLS/HTTPS, VPNs, secure DNS, certificate pinning

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 1.pptx

document:
Summary
• Cyber attacks target CIA triad
• Malware types include viruses, worms, trojans, ransomware
• Social engineering exploits human weaknesses
• Mitigation: layered defense, user training, and patch management
